channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pistorius to Face Psychiatric Assessment
item.description: The examination was ordered after a defense witness in the Pistorius murder trial testified that the athlete suffered from a generalized anxiety disorder.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Charges of Chinese Cyberspying, Wanted Posters Included
item.description: The five members of China’s military accused of hacking against American companies are at the top of the F.B.I. “Cyber’s Most Wanted” list, but little has been revealed about them beyond their names and aliases.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Wanted posters identified the Chinese military personnel the United States has linked to cyberespionage.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Rare, Partial Victory in Saving Remnants of Old Beijing
item.description: In a first, a Beijing resident has won protected status for what remains of two sites of historical value from the city’s cultural authorities.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Cui Jinze stands below the hanging lotus gate at No. 33 Lingjing Lane. The empty rectangles along the top of the gate show where thieves removed carved panels in January.

item.title: Fukushima Workers Fled Plant After Accident Despite Orders
item.description: A previously undisclosed interview with the plant manager described the panic among workers at the most dire moment of the nuclear disaster.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Defense Statement on the U.S. Cyberspying Indictment
item.description: In a statement, the Chinese Ministry of National Defense condemned the United States indictments of five Chinese military officers on charges of hacking into commercial networks to steal corporate secrets.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Imposing Martial Law, Thai Military Denies Plans for Coup
item.description: With concerns about the motives of the Thai military, one politician called the declaration of martial law “softer than a coup.”
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Pedestrians strolled past armed Thai soldiers guarding a government building in Bangkok after martial law was declared.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Reporters on ‘Gutter Oil’ Series Assaulted, People’s Daily Says
item.description: The Communist Party news organization said its reporters were attacked and robbed of their cameras and cellphones while investigating “gutter oil,” waste cooking oil that is illegally reused.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: One researcher estimated that as many as 10 percent of restaurant meals were cooked with tainted oil.

item.title: U.S. Cites End to C.I.A. Ruses Using Vaccines
item.description: A top White House official has pledged that the C.I.A. will no longer use vaccination programs as cover for spying operations.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: General Declares Martial Law Across Thailand Amid Paralyzing Protests
item.description: The head of Thailand’s army declared what he described as nationwide martial law early Tuesday and urged protesters who have blocked elections to “stop their movement.”
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Pedestrians strolled past armed Thai soldiers guarding a government building in Bangkok after martial law was declared.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: U.S. to Bolster Search
item.description: The United States has reached an agreement with Nigeria to share some intelligence to bolster the search for more than 200 girls kidnapped by the group Boko Haram.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: The Netherlands: Heroin Seized
item.description: Nearly 1,700 pounds of heroin was smuggled into the Netherlands last week hidden in a shipment of Iranian raisins.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: Separatists Free Hostages
item.description: Separatists in northern Mali have released about 30 civil servants held since Saturday after an attack on a regional governor’s office in Kidal.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: India Ink: In Modi’s Twitter Diplomacy, A Notable Omission
item.description: Narendra Modi thanks, and ignores, world leaders on Twitter.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: The Lede: Video Shows Killing of Palestinians on ‘Nakba Day’
item.description: Security-camera footage obtained by a rights group appears to show the fatal shooting of two young Palestinians during a demonstration in Beitunia, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: As Pope’s Visit Nears, Hate Crimes a Concern in Israel
item.description: Israeli authorities are working to contain vandalism, like the recent defacing of a church in Jerusalem, but say there are challenges.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Vigil Marks 1,000 Days of Detention of American Marine in Iran
item.description: Family and supporters of Amir Hekmati, accused of “practical collaboration with the American government,” gathered in front of the White House.
item.dc:creator: By JADA F. SMITH

item.title: Food Crisis Worsens in South Sudan as Civil War Is Displacing Millions
item.description: Officials warn that the thousands of deaths and the displacement of one million people could be only the beginning of the trouble in South Sudan.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: A Political Dynasty in India After a Crippling Defeat
item.description: A meeting of the Indian National Congress did little to address flaws in a campaign that failed to connect with young voters, reducing the party’s representation in the lower house of Parliament from 206 seats to 44.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: The Indian National Congress president, Sonia Gandhi, and Rahul Gandhi, her son and party vice president, at a meeting Monday in New Delhi.

item.title: Libyans Begin Taking Sides After General Wages Attacks
item.description: The interim government proposed selecting a new prime minister and suspending Parliament in an effort to defuse tensions, but militias and other groups started to align themselves with or against the renegade general, Khalifa Heftar.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Ukraine Crisis Pushing Putin Toward China
item.description: Conciliatory remarks on Ukraine by President Vladimir V. Putin were probably intended for China, where he arrives Tuesday determined to strengthen “mutually beneficial trade and economic ties.”
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: 5 in China Army Face U.S. Charges of Cyberattacks
item.description: The Department of Justice charged five individuals from the People’s Liberation Army in connection with stealing trade secrets from American companies.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Press material displayed before Mr. Holder at the news conference on Monday.

item.title: Flood Danger Persists in Serbia, Threatening Power Plant
item.description: Workers have so far been unsuccessful at building a barricade of sandbags to save the coal-fired Nikola Tesla power plant that provides half of the nation’s electricity.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Destruction in the village of Krupanj, west of Serbia’s capital, Belgrade, on Monday. Recent rains caused the worst flooding in Serbia and Bosnia since records began being kept 120 years ago.

item.title: Cheating Death, and the Rumor Mill, in North Korea
item.description: Hyon Song-wol was reported to be a former girlfriend of the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Hyon Song-wol, in a YouTube still, was said to have been shot on orders of Kim Jong-un.

item.title: Cleric Convicted of All Terrorism Charges
item.description: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, a former imam who prosecutors said had “devoted his life to violent jihad,” was convicted of 11 terrorism-related charges on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, who is also known as Abu Hamza al-Masri, could face life in prison.

item.title: Koseler Journal: After Mine Disaster, a Painful Awareness of What Has Been Lost
item.description: In Turkey, where 301 men were killed when a fire tore through a coal mine last week, people are beginning to consider the costs of a new way of life that emerged over the past decade.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
